data.name: heading
data.body: Cells in Series and in Parallel

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Cells in an electric circuit can be combined, similar to how resistors are combined. When cells are connected in series (one terminal of each cell is joined together), their individual electromotive forces (emfs) and internal resistances add up.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: For example, if we have two cells with emfs \( e_1 \) and \( e_2 \), and internal resistances \( r_1 \) and \( r_2 \), connected in series, the total emf (\( e_{\text{eq}} \)) and total internal resistance (\( r_{\text{eq}} \)) of the combination are:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: If the negative terminal of the second cell is connected to the positive terminal of the first, the emf of the combination is \( e_{\text{eq}} = e_1 - e_2 \).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: When cells are connected in parallel (positive terminals together, negative terminals together), the total emf and total internal resistance are calculated differently. For two cells in parallel, the total emf (\( e_{\text{eq}} \)) and total internal resistance (\( r_{\text{eq}} \)) are:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: These formulas hold when the current leaves each cell from the positive terminal. If the current leaves from the negative terminal, the sign of the emf changes accordingly.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: For a parallel combination of \( n \) cells, the equivalent emf (\( e_{\text{eq}} \)) and internal resistance (\( r_{\text{eq}} \)) are calculated by averaging the individual emfs and internal resistances.
